items.title: Our journey with Autism (Part 2)
items.summary: Self-care is the highest form of loveI didn't know how strong I was until I was faced with the desperate…
items.content_html:
Self-care is the highest form of love

I didn't know how strong I was until I was faced with the desperate situation of Liam's autism. It is almost like going on an auto-pilot mode. The mum's instinct to protect and fight for her child. 

Looking back, those early years were a blur. They consist of intensive therapies, fingers crossing, huge disappointments but celebrations of little successes. If you ask me, I have become a better person in every way through the curve that was thrown at me. It has taught me patience, persistence, love, forgiveness and basically every difficult form of traits that one would rather not acquire. 

I want to speak to the special needs parents specifically about forgiving yourself. I carried the guilt for a long time. The nudging feeling of guilt and self-blame. I was convinced Liam was autistic because I painted the house and inhaled the paint fumes (How ridiculous). I later on met an anti-vaxer lady that told me vaccinations causes autism and it is a conspiracy by the Australian government (Man that was an eventful day I never saw her again). 

Does it matter really if we find out the reason why our child has autism? We will still love them and would fight for them. I have to forgive myself, for not doing enough, for doing too much, for being tired, for resenting, for wanting a normal family, for losing hope, for the past, for the present and for what is to come. 

When we forgive ourselves, we allow hope to fill our hearts and this gives us energy for the future to fight. Self-care is not selfish, it is the highest form of love we can offer to ourselves and our family.

May you be kind to yourself today x

items.title: Our journey with Autism (Part 1)
items.summary: This will be the first of many posts which I will talk about our journey with autism. I will include…
items.content_html:
This will be the first of many posts which I will talk about our journey with autism. I will include our experiences in dealing with the landscape of both Singapore and Australia's special needs support. I hoped this series of posts on our experiences would shine a light on autism and be helpful in some ways.

I am careful to talk about Liam as I do not want to invade into his privacy or overstep his consent. My concern is not to leave any permanent digital footprint about him without him truly understanding the ramifications of it. Having to say that, I am happy to take it offline with any parents should you have any similar concern about your child. 

I have had a normal and healthy pregnancy. If anything I gained too much weight. I was an oversized dinosaur waddling when I was into my 3rd trimester. The delivery was long but it was alright. I have filled up hundreds of forms regarding Liam's diagnosis and they always ask similar questions if the pregnancy and delivery were normal.

Liam was a happy baby and toddler. He has had developmental delays but we chalked it to the fact that boys usually develop later than girls. When he was 2, he started to have uncontrollable meltdowns. Looking back, it was a combination of the fact that he wasn't able to express himself (as he was non-verbal at the time), and he wasn't able to cope with the sensory overloads. We were really helpless and isolated because in the asian culture, there is a strong stigma of having a child with mental disability. 

He was diagnosed when he was 4. We waited 1.5 year for early intervention support but it was taking too long for us. We were not equipped to help him and our daily life was beyond stressful. We tried 2 preschools and they could not cope with him. Those were really dark days because nothing we do seems to help him at all. It was very stressful in Singapore because we find that there was a lack of empathy and understanding at that point. This was about 6 years ago. I would like to to believe Singapore has progressed in this aspect. 

The turning point truly came for us when we relocated to Sydney, Australia. We received funding for his therapy from the government and there were endless options of support for his well-being here. I had to change my perspective from having no support to picking the suitable one for him. We had an intensive year of therapies ranging from psychology, behavioural, speech and occupational. They were essential to help him to be independent and cope with life. 

He has come on leaps and bounds. We have had many people who told us that they cannot tell that Liam has autism. I am not so sure about that statement. Autism is an invisible disability. It can actually work for and against him. I will elaborate on this on my following posts.

Singapore parents who are struggling with their children on the autism spectrum and finding it difficult in Singapore, please do not think that relocating to other countries is the only solution. The whole world has moved into teleconferencing and online communication due to Covid. You can access to any training or therapy not limited to what Singapore provides. Moreover, it is about finding the right therapy, providing a safe and consistent environment for your child. As parents progress, children progresses too. 

I am including some objective helpful readings if you suspect your child has autism. I can't stress enough how important it is not to get into non-mainstream ideas like curing autism through diet, being anti-vax and so on. Don't be taken on a ride. They usually sell you the idea of hope. Accept your child for who he or she is. This is the first step to finding light at the end of the tunnel.

Please reach out and I will be happy to give more information from our experiences.

Sending you light and love x

For Sydney residents:

Autism Aspect Australia

Autism Community Network

For Singapore residents:

Autism Resource Centre

MSF - Early Signs of ASD

items.title: Vtech Kidizoom Duo Camera
items.summary: Lily received her first birthday present this year from her Grandma in Singapore. She asked for a pink camera…
items.content_html:
Lily received her first birthday present this year from her Grandma in Singapore. She asked for a pink camera because she loves pink for everything and she was coveting after Levi's camera for a while now.

We combed through the web and realised Vtech Kidizoom Duo Camera has received raving reviews above the rest. It is on the pricier side but we wanted to get something that is durable and educational. Vtech has a good reputation of creating toys that has educational value. We have had their toys for both the boys before and they played with them for a long time. 

The camera has a front and rear photo-taking function. It is up to date for the selfies-wefies generation. It has built-in auto-flash, large colour screen, 4x digital zoom and also voice recorder with voice changing effects and built-in games. The games were something I wasn't keen on. Lily tried to play with them but she was too young for it. She ended up throwing a tantrum which was too familiar in my household. My kids has a bad rep of throwing tantrums over screens, ipads and technology. 

I wasn't keen on Lily or the boys hogging on the camera for the games. The problem with my kids at the moment is once they get on the screen, they get stimulated to the point where any other activity seems boring to them. So I just didn't want to dig myself another hole. 

Anyway, Brandon discovered that the games can be disabled. So it comes with parental control for that. Well done VTech, for considering the luddites mum like me.

We disabled the game function and let the kids use the camera as it is. And Lily has used it to take many unflattering photos of me, which I will spare you the agony of them.

Overall, it is a good buy and investment. It is a good present for kids as well. It is recommended for ages 3-9 so I can see it being used across my kids who happens to be age 3, 6 and 9. 

For more information on Vtech Kidizoom products, please click here.

items.title: Custom Cubbys & Tee Pees
items.summary: When we moved into our current home years ago, the previous owner left behind a timber playset. It was…
items.content_html:
When we moved into our current home years ago, the previous owner left behind a timber playset. It was perfect for the 3 kids then. They were aged 1, 4 and 7. The kids were on it every single day.

As the kids grow, we realised they were growing out of the playset. They were bored with it. Eventually they were doing dangerous stunts on it, climbing on top of the roof and doing silly things. Liam was very fixated on the idea of a treehouse ever since Brandon shared with him on how he always wanted one growing up. Having a space for Liam to reset his sensory challenges has always been an essential for him too. 

I started researching on the possibility of having a treehouse. But we don't have a tree! Seems pretty unusual because Sydney homes usually have a few at their front or backyards. In Liam's usual fashion, he asked me to grow a tree for it. His mind has no concept on limits. So the next thing was getting a cubby. Most flat packed cubbies are good for toddlers and young kids. Their entry usually would not exceed 1.2m. So our first priority is to have a cubby that would suit them for years, not just at their current age. 

I understand there's a cost involved in having a big investment. So we did it the Neo's way. We saved for it. Our home only consists of legos (mostly given or hand-me-downs), and books. We do not purchase toys which always go into landfills anyway. Our previous big purchase was the trampoline and the kids goes on it every single day.

After almost 6 months of researching and correspondences with different cubby companies in Australia, we finally decided on Custom Cubbys & Tee Pees. It was a thoroughly good experience dealing with owners Darren and Renee. Nothing was too much of a hassle for them. They answered every query I had promptly and professionally. We had to use a freight company as their company was based in Victoria. 

We were kept abreast on the progress of the cubby. The mark of a good company is when owners take pride in what they do. They made sure we levelled the ground properly on our end before the cubby came. It was a smooth process for us even though the cubby was coming from interstate and we had to install it on our own. 

We chose a white fibreglass slide and coordinate the cubby colors based on our home's. It is a visual goal that we will evict the kids eventually to the cubby. 

We will not hesitate to recommend Darren and Renee for their professionalism, workmanshop and heart in what they do. 

Photo by Eric Yip @ https://eyxl.com.au/

Contact Info:

Phone: 0419 331 243
Email: customcubbys@bigpond.com
Facebook Instagram

items.title: Coffee Trad3rs
items.summary: Our good friend has recommended Coffee Trad3rs to us sometimes back. The owner, James, a Taiwanese has a wealth…
items.content_html:
Our good friend has recommended Coffee Trad3rs to us sometimes back. The owner, James, a Taiwanese has a wealth of experience in the cafe industry. His previous stint was in Malaysia helping a friend to set up a cafe. 

We decided to hit the cafe during Father's Day weekend. To be honest, we weren't sure about moving to Hills District but we have been pleasantly surprised by the community so far. There is a good mix of nature and shopping districts littered everywhere. People are alot laid back here, and always happy to strike up a convo. 

Upon entering the cafe, you would be overwhelmed by the number of indoor plants who are thriving and happy. James is the main vibe of the cafe. He is chirpy, loud and engaging. You could see straightaway that he is gifted to do this.

The coffee and food were phenomenal. There was a Father's Day special, pork knuckle. I wasn't keen on the meat so I devoured the rest of the vegetables. Every single dish tasted differently and you could tell care and thought were put into preparing them. 

We had the 3 kids with us and it is always a challenge to keep them occupied. Levi would get bored very easily and he would lead the pack to be silly. We have to juggle to keep them seated and happy before they embark on this slippery road of no return (Pun intended). There were so many times we have to leave and return home. Stories for another day.

James was very attentive and kept coming back to the table to engage the kids. He promised them ice-cream (The cafe has their own gelato chest!). Mind you, it was a full house indoor and outdoor. James was not just interested to earn your bucks, he was about heart and making friendship. We left the place with our hearts full that day. 

You can't counterfeit heart and sincerity in doing business. People can tell. 

Anyway, it is definitely worth a visit if you are in the area. Good coffee and good food. The setting is serene if it's not busy but buzzing with life it is. Look out for James, he might give you a gelato.

Coffee Traders
Shop 1 / 8 Victoria Avenue,
Castle Hill, NSW
Mon-Fri: 6am – 4pm
Sat: 7:30am – 3:30pm
Sun: Closed
 
Website Instagram Facebook

items.title: Who Are We
items.summary: We are Neorotribe. We are a tribe of 2 parents and 3 beautiful children. Our family name is Neo. You…
items.content_html:
We are Neorotribe. We are a tribe of 2 parents and 3 beautiful children. Our family name is Neo. You would have guessed by now.

Dad is Brandon. Mum is June. Follow by firstborn Liam who is beautiful, kind, unassuming and just so happens to have autism. Second-born Levi is sensitive, free-spirited and marked by his grandma's dimples. And lastly, the princess of our tribe Lily is endearing in every way. 

We are from Singapore and have made Sydney Australia our home since 2016. The journey here has been amazing and challenging at the same time. We have been broken and healed, inundated by our experiences. Nonetheless, we would like to think there are also interesting and funny experiences that are worth sharing. We hoped you would be enriched and inspired by our stories.

Don't be a stranger and say hello below.

items.title: Taronga Zoo
items.summary: Everytime we visit Taronga Zoo, our experience is always different, in a good way. The view of the harbour…
items.content_html:
Everytime we visit Taronga Zoo, our experience is always different, in a good way. The view of the harbour would almost always guarantee a mood lift. Today we got there around lunch time. Kids were excited as usual. They are pretty straight forward, they are happy when they get to go free range. 

I was just a little nervous when we saw the line to the seal show. It was a massive queue and there weren't much social distancing. We made our way against the traffic of people and made a beeline to the playground. I think any person that has gone to Taronga enough with food can tell you the resident turkeys there are relentless. They are really aggressive and no longer afraid of humans. The whole stress about guarding your children's food became like a chore really. We ended up force-feeding our children at double the speed while wary-eyed of the turkeys the whole time. I supposed tourists would find this fascinating and wouldn't mind the experience of kookaburras swopping down on your fish-and-chips or turkeys ransacking your snackbag. 

And a heads up, the usual main restaurant near the elephant enclosure is open for takeaway but not for sit down dining. BYOF. And maybe a red hot chilli and feed it to the turkey when it gets too annoying (I am kidding!). 

If you fancy a good exercise, you will work your glutes in the zoo walking up and down the slopes. It is especially intense on the way out to the exit. This is why I got my 9 yo Liam to push the stroller up today. Return of Investment. HA HA.

I still think the zoo is a relatively safe place for a family day out in regards to the Covid situation. There are plenty of greens and spots for a sit down picnic. Some animals enclosures are pretty small and it does get a little crowded for my liking. But as parents it is on us to practice common sense and remind our kids about keeping their distance and maintaining their hygiene. 

Taronga Zoo also made provision for the autism community. Guests with autism and their family and friends get to enjoy early entry to the zoo on select days in the year. There is also an option of the zoo team providing extra assistance should there be a need. Read more here.

Due to the current COVID-19 safety restrictions, all visitors are required to purchase tickets online (with up to 20% savings online!) and attend the Zoo on their selected date only. Tickets will not be available for purchase at the gate. If you plan to visit Taronga Zoo this season, you are advised to book online prior to attending. This is to prevent overcrowding and ensure social distancing measures can be effective. 

Enjoy your Taronga Zoo visit!

items.title: Hills Swimming
items.summary: Prior to moving to Hills district, I was concerned having to start all over finding our community. So far…
items.content_html:
Prior to moving to Hills district, I was concerned having to start all over finding our community. So far we have been extremely surprised by the wide array of quality providers of kids' activities, cafes, parks, amenities and all. 

Swimming is a lifeskill so it is compulsory in our family. It was tricky for us to find the right one as Liam was having difficulties in a group swimming setting before. Our current challenge is to find a swimming place that can accommodate our 3 kids level and timing. 

We pulled the kids out of all their activities when the world came to an end in March (Feels like it in my part of the world!). 

At this unprecedented season, there is a certain sense of heightened cautiousness and fear when we send our kids back to their usual activities. My aim is to provide an insight on how well a place or provider is adhering to the covidsafe rules and regulations. This will provide you a peace of mind and let you know what to expect when you visit the place.

Today marks the first time Lily is swimming. I was really impressed when we stepped into the vicinity. Entry and Exit were marked clearly at the door. You would hit the sanitiser station first and staff will take both yours and your child's temperature. You will then be directed to leave your details for contact tracing. The process was without dramas even though I had Lily with me. Perhaps it would be a different story with the boys.

All the ground staffs were wearing masks and the swimming instructors in the pool were wearing a plastic shield. All the seatings were spaced out which is a relief. The pool do get a little crowded at some point but I do feel safe because I could smell the sanitiser in both seating and pool area. I must say the staffs has taken effort to be warm and engaging despite wearing the masks. 

It is really hard to be running a local business providing service at this Covid season. Everyone is trying their best to make it work. I do appreciate the fact that I can send my children in to continue their swimming activity in a safe and protected environment.

For this I would give Hills Swimming a 5/5 rating as a covidsafe provider. This is on top of their excellent swimming curriculum which has stood the rest of time for many Hills district parents over the years.

For more information on Hills Swimming, you can click here. Begin your child's swimming journey by booking in a trial lesson here.

items.title: Authenticity = Happiness
items.summary: This year I gained a valuable piece of wisdom. I wanted to be happier, to be more present and…
items.content_html:
This year I gained a valuable piece of wisdom. I wanted to be happier, to be more present and to be more authentic.

You know as a parent you can get away with saying anything when your kids are young. They do not know any better nor judge you. Now that my kids are older, they would often retort back. "Why do you say stupid, that is not nice" or "Why do you whinge when you ask me not to?" You just can't have double standards anymore. 

And quitting the double standards actually inched me forward to be a more authentic and happier individual. There used to be a disparity in what I say and how I feel. It is probably a learnt behaviour growing up. I would say what I don't mean. I have mastered a skill of saying what people wants to hear. I have quit flattery so that was not an issue for me in recent times. 

Let me give you a scenario to illustrate my point better.

Let's say I were to help a fellow friend with moving home. I appear to be willing and empathetic to my friend but complained about how tired it was to my husband after. I realised this disparity in between has caused me my happiness and my reliability with my children. So I decided to close this disparity gap for good.

If I were to say something, I stay consistent in my word and thoughts. I quit being flippant or fickle. This has also helped me to stop overpromising and underdelivering in my life in general. I could write a thousand essays on this alone.

Saying what you mean and meaning what you say happens to be the golden mantra of Brandon's too. He talks about it all the time with the kids. He is such an amazing human and the kids know he follow through what he promises each time. This is also why threatening our children never works and always end up backfiring on us. We all strive to be good reliable dependable parents to our children and one of the most important thing is to follow through our words, in punishment or in rewards. 

What words do you use? What would you say? Do you find that being authentic is to stay consistent to your words in front and behind the scenes?

items.title: Play
items.summary: My kids love to play. Which kid doesn't? Unfortunately between play and having screen time, they would gladly choose…
items.content_html:
My kids love to play. Which kid doesn't? Unfortunately between play and having screen time, they would gladly choose the latter. 

This is why Brandon and I are huge advocates at providing the environment for them to play. We are not big on accumulating toys and are minimalists by nature. So at any one time in the house, there is only a set of toy and activity. At this moment it's LEGO. We would never say no to books so they are everywhere in our home. 

We are very fortunate to have a yard in our home. The trampoline has been a daily routine for my kids. We recently added a cubby because the kids had bugged us for the past year for a treehouse. We don't have a tree and the cubby is the next best thing. We chose a big cubby as Liam could not fit into a toddler's one anymore. We hoped it would serve as a hideout and probably even a kiddy flat for them. 

My kids understand the drill in the house. They would usually get out and play themselves. Unless there is a fight incident among them, they can go on for hours. I have also trained myself to resist helping them with their boredom. I have never gave in to them when they come to me and say they are bored. They have a million things to do if they dig deep into their imagination. And usually after some time, they would find something to do. 

It takes practice for both you and your children to get into the routine. I never like placing my kids in front of a TV. They are losing precious time with each other bonding and making memories. I let them get dirty and messy in the yard. There is so much the great outdoors could offer to both the kids and adults. 

This is why I love being in the garden, working the lawn or caring for the plants. It does my soul so so good. My kids are also much calmer when they get to play in the sun and get some fresh air.

Rewild and rewire yourself with your own family culture. It is a little tweak but it would bring so much happiness in the long run. Try it.

Photo by Eric Yip @ https://eyxl.com.au/
